coredata.dc:title: Plastic and glassy crystalline states of methane: A Monte Carlo simulation study
coredata.dc:creator: Yashonath, S.
Rao, C.N.R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A Monte Carlo simulation study has been carried out on the glassy crystalline phases of methane obtained by annealing or quenching the plastic (orientationally disordered) phase. Different cooling rates lead to different states of the glass. Temperature variation of the reorientational parameter suggests the presence of a transition between the plastic and glassy crystalline phases.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 101. number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 November 1983 PLASTIC AND GLASSY CRYSTALLINE STATES OF METHANE: A MONTE CARLO SIMULATION STUDY * S. YASHONATH and C.N.R. RAO Solid State ami Structural Oiemistry Unit, Indian Institute of Science. Bangalore-360012, India Received 16 August 1983 A Monte Carlo simuLition study ha! been carried out on the glassy crystalline pliases of meth.me obtained by dnnealing nr qucncliins; the plastic (oricntalion^Uy disordered) phase. Dit'ferent cooling rates lead to different states of the glass- Tempera- ture ^..irution of the rconcnuiional parameter suggests the presence of a transition between the plastic and glassy crystalline phabcs. 1. Introduction Phase transitions of solid methane have attracted much interest in recent years [1 3] and three well- defined phases of methane, I, II and 111. have been establislied. Phase I of a face-centered cubic structure occurs from the triplet point (90 K) down to 20-4 K. wlien it transforms to pliase II without a change in structure: III is a high-pressure phase. Phase I is an orientationaiiy disordered (plastically crystalline) pluse. while phase II is the well-known James Keenun (JK) phase [4] - In tlie JK phase, six out of eight molecules are orientationaiiy disordered and the remaining two perform nearly free rotation; this phase has been investigated by a variety of techniques [5 8]- Bounds el al. [9] have recently carried out a molecular dynamics calculation on the orientationally disordered phase I and evaluated the static ",nd dy- namic structure factors while Murad el cl. [10] have performed calculations on liquid methane. We have carried out a Monte Carlo simulation study of the pliases obtained by the step-wise cooling or quench- ing of the plastically crystalline phase of methane. Studies of such orientational glasses or glassy crystals [11] by computer simulation are of considerable in- terest in view of the observation that properties and * Contribution No. 219 from the Solid State and Structural Cheniistrv Unit. structure of positionally disordered glasses are inde- pendent of quenching rate [12,13]. Furthermore, it was of interest to see if the calculations would pre- dict a transition from tlie plastic phase to the glassy phase- 2. Method of calculation We have carried out Monte Carlo calculations in tlie NVT ensemble employing the Metropolis scheme on a system of 32 or 108 molecules. The molecules were treated as rigid with tlie carbon atoms fixed at the fee lattice sites and possessing 3N rotational de- grees of freedom. We did not introduce any change in the lattice parameter with temperature; it is note- worthy that there is only a very small change in the lattice parameter [14,15] going from phase II (5.895 A) to phase I (5-92 A at 30 K). We have employed a lattice parameter value of 5.896 A and a C H bond- length of 1 -09 A in all our simulation studies. We have employed an atom atom potential of the form r^^) --W^ -^P ^-^ap) where ass = CJH,r^g is the distance from atom ac of one molecule to atom ss of a different molecule. The potential parameters (set VII) of Williams [16] were used in the study. We have considered only the nearest- 524 0 009-2614/83/0000-0000/S 03.00 1983 North-Holland Volume 101, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 November 1983 and next-nearest-neighbour interactions with periodic boundary conditions and expressed molecular orien- tations in terms of the three Euler angles (^,0,V'). We have defined a reorientational parameter i? to quanti- fy the magnitude of rotation as follows: 4 i?=Zi min{|7^0,0,^)-7^0+50,0+50, ^+oi^)|, /'= 1,4}. Here,7. and7. denotes the position of the hydrogen before and after a trial rotation; i? is averaged for each of the molecules individually. We first performed MC calculations on the plastic phase at 70 or 85 K. Subsequently, the plastic phase was cooled to different temperatures (40,35,30, 25, 22.5,21,20.5,20,19,18 and 15 K) in a step-wise manner and allowed to equilibrate at each of these temperatures; we refer to these phases as annealed phases. Pair distribution functions and the reorien- tational parameter T} were then calculated at selected temperatures. We have also calculated tile properties of a phase obtained by abruptly quenching the plas- tic phase from 70 to 80 K. We have compared the properties of the quenched phase with those of the annealed phase at the same temperature. 3. Results and discussion In fig. 1 we have depicted the molecular orienta- tion in the plastic (and JK) phases obtained by com- puter simulation. We readily see random orientation of the molecules in the plastic phase and orientational order in the JK phase. Our MC calculations yield a configurational energy of 7.95 0-08 kJ mol"1, for the plastic phase without any truncation and size cor- rection. The,gy^(7-) pair distribution function (PDF) obtained by us for the plastic phase (fig. 2) is similar to that obtained by Bounds et al. [9] and corre- sponds closely to that of the liquid phase [10]. The gCH^) PDF calculated by us is somewhat sharper, showing a more intense 5 A peak possibly because of the rigid lattice constraint used in the present study. It is noteworthy that the PDFs obtained with 32 mol- ecules are nearly the same as those with 108 mole- cules. In fig. 2 we have shown g^H^1') an'^ gc^(r) PDFs Fig- 1. Typical molecular arrangement of a molecule with its twelve nearest neighbours of (a) James Keenan, (b) plastical- ly crystalline (ai 70 K), (c) annealed (at 18 K) and (d) quenched (at 18 K) phases of metliane obtained from com- puter simulation- Fig. 2. ^HH an^ SCH P311' distribution functions for plastic, annealed (A) and quenched phases (Q). 525 Volume 101. number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 November 1983 for various annealed phases (at different temperatures) of methane. The peaks in the g^ ^(r) and gc^(r) PDFs become increasingly sharper with decrease in temperature. At 18 K.^y(r) shows five peaks with iwo prominent peaks at 4.2 and 5.2 A. In fig. 2. we have also shown the PDFs of the phase obtained by quenching the plastic crystal to 18 K- The quenched phase PDF gu nO") sliows six peaks with three peaks at 4.2,4.9 and 5.3 A. the last two peaks originating from the 5.2 A peak of the annealed phase. While di- rect comparison of intensities is made difficult by the overlap of peaks, the peak intensity ratio, /(4.2)/ 1(4.9 + 5.3).in the non-overlapping region changes from 1.0 in tlie quenched phase to 1.3 in the anneal- ed phase (at 18 K). In the SCH^ of the annealed phase, tlie peak at 4.2 A is somewhat more intense and in addition there is a small peak at 3.8 A, a fea- ture that is absent in the quenched phase. These ob- servations suggest that tlie pliases (at 18 K) obtained by quenching and annealing represent two different states. In dg. l we have shown tlie orientation of mole- cules in tlie quenched and annealed pliases at 18 K. Fig. 1 clearly demonstrates that we do indeed obtain different types of frozen orientations by employing different quenching rates- That we can obtain two different glassy states by varying quenching rates is interesting and differs from tlie earlier observation [12.13,17] based on computer simulation studies that different rates of quenching lead to tlie same fi- nal coiifiguration. Angell [17] has recently suggested that hysteresis effects may reflect thermal history. Tlie present study sliows that the PDF is itself sensi- tive 10 the quenching rate. Tlie relative changes observed in tlie PDF of tlie annealed phase at 18 K. can be interpreted in terms of the JK pliase which is the stable phase at this temper- ature. Accordingly, . 11 u (r) of the JK phase shows major peaks at 4.1,4.3.4.6 and 5.0 A and the inten- sity in the 4.0 4.7 A region is about three times the intensity in tlie region 4-7 5.6 A. The gc^(r) of the JK pliase shows a peak at 3.8 A. These features are similar to those of the annealed phases at low temper- atures discussed above, suggesting that the annealed pluse lends towards to JK. phase. We have evaluated the magnitude of reorientational motion in the plastic and the annealed phases in terms of TI at various temperatures- In fig. 3 we have plotted 526 -70 - -30 -oo, 20 40 60 T.K 80 Fig- 3. Varution of reorientational motion with temperature. Tlie dotted line is dra^n only as a guide to the eye. The angu- lar buckets indicate aver.iging over the lattice <i}2) against temperature; in the same figure we have also plotted the configurational energy against tem- perature. The reorientational motion decreases gradu- ally with decrease in temperature and exhibits a fairly sharp decrease around 27 K. Below 20 K, i? essential- ly remains constant. The annealed phase below 20 K may be taken to represent a metastable thermody- namic state- The sharp decrease in reorientational pa- rameter around 27 K suggests a transition, possibly akin to tlie glass transition exhibited by plastic crys- tals. The smeared nature of the O?2)-?' curve in fig. 3 may be a consequence of the high quenching rate which is intrinsic to computer simulation studies. Ul- trasonic measurements of viscous liquids also show sucli a smeared transition at high frequencies [18]. We are continuing the investigations of tlie various crystalline states of methane by taking account of the change in shape of the simulation box with tempera- ture using a Monte Carlo algorithm analogous to that used by Parrinello et al. [19] in their molecular dy- namics studies. We believe this will enable us to in- vestigate crystal crystal, plastic crystal crystal and plastic crystal glassy crystal transitions. We expect to report these results in the near future. References {l ] C- Chdpados and A- Cabana. Chem. Phys- Letters 7 (1970)191. [2] A.1. Nijman and AJ. Berlinsky, Phys. Rev. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A Monte Carlo simulation study has been carried out on the glassy crystalline phases of methane obtained by annealing or quenching the plastic (orientationally disordered) phase. Different cooling rates lead to different states of the glass. Temperature variation of the reorientational parameter suggests the presence of a transition between the plastic and glassy crystalline phases.
